newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt, EU edge towards partnership agreement.
newsitem.headline: Egypt, EU edge towards partnership agreement.

text.p: Egypt and the European Union, at talks in Brussels last week, edged close to a partnership agreement providing for free trade in services and manufactured goods, the Egyptian negotiator said on Wednesday.

Ambassador Gamal Bayyoumi told Reuters the European negotiators had stopped talking about traditional trade flows and said they could offer new quotas for Egypt's agricultural exports to Europe -- the main bone of contention in the talks.
"Now they have realised that traditional flows of trade are a silly thing to talk about. They mentioned that they can propose new (quota) figures. Now we can talk," he said.
"It seemed that they could read the political message and they said they have a more flexible stance. They started to talk more sense, even if it's not enough," he added.
Egypt is pressing for easier access to European Union (EU) markets for Egyptian foodstuffs, especially rice and potatoes.

The EU, hamstrung by the Common Agricultural Policy, has previously argued for quotas that reflect the historical level of Egyptian exports. Egypt says these are based on a time when it traded mainly with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Bayyoumi said he had three days of talks with Enrico Cioffi, director of external relations at the European Commission, and representatives of all 15 EU member states.
The Egyptian diplomat had already dismissed the previous quota proposals by the EU. "I gave them a flat no (in December). It was a kind of joke," he said on Wednesday.
The next move is for the representatives of the member states to consult their governments and come back to Egypt with a date for the next formal meeting, Bayyoumi said.

"They want to reach an agreement or at least an agreement in principle by Malta in April," he added. Mediterranean states will meet in Malta for a round of talks on cooperation between the countries on the northern and southern shores of the sea.
"So now there is time pressure on the European side. Malta is a sort of pressure," Bayyoumi said.
Egypt argues that the EU must be more flexible on its agricultural imports if it wants its southern neighbours to take talk of cooperation seriously.
